chapter.title: Using the Administrative Interface
chapter.para:
Once the ⪚ is set up and initial configuration complete, further administration of the ⪚ generally takes place from the Administrative Interface. The Administrative Interface is launched from the appliance or a Web Browser. To launch the Administrative Interface from the appliance, simply right click on the desktop and click on "Metavize Client." To launch the Administrative Interface from a remote machine, point your browser window at the following address (URL).
http://your_internal_ip
Where your_internal_ip is replaced with the internal IP address of your ⪚. If you do not know the internal IP address of the ⪚, please refer to . After accessing the URL, you should see a page similar to that shown in .

In the center of the screen is a link Launch EdgeGuard Client. Clicking on this link begins the process of launching the Administrative Interface. You may receive a warning from your web browser regarding certificates, example of such a warning is shown in .

It is safe to dismiss this warning, as you are connecting to the ⪚ appliance.
Depending on your web browser and operating system, you may be prompted to install Java Web Start. This is an additional browser technology required to run the Administrative Interface. Please follow the instructions provided in your browser to install Java Web Start.
The first time you launch the Administrative Interface from a given machine, it may take a few moments to download the required files, as shown in .
Once the Administrative Interface is loaded, you will be prompted to provide a username and password to log in, as seen in .

The initial Login is admin and the initial Password is passwd. Please make a note that you should change this default password (as described in ). If all goes correctly, you should see the initial Administrative Interface screen as shown in .
If you see the screen shown in , please proceed to for an overview of the Administrative Interface then for a discussion of installing Software Appliances.
If you encounter problems launching the Administrative Interface, please consult the Frequently Asked Question section for more assistance.

sect1.title: Navigation
sect1.para: In this section, we will introduce the overall layout and navigation of the Administrative Interface. The Administrative Interface is laid out as a set of global controls to the left, and a Virtual Rack to the right. The metaphor presented by the interface is similar to the physical network rack (a cabinet with a collection of hardware) seen in many organizations. The complete layout is seen in .
The image shown in has several numbered call-outs. The meaning of these elements is as follows.

listitem.para: This is the Store tab, listing any Software Appliances available yet not purchased.
This is the Toolbox tab, listing any Software Appliances available to install. When installed, Software Appliances appear gray in this list and are expanded in the Virtual Rack to the right.
This is the Config tab, providing access to global properties. These are properties of your ⪚, which are not unique to a single Software Appliance. Using the Config tab is covered later in .
This is the Policy and Virtual Rack selector. Configuring Policies and multiple Virtual Racks is an advanced feature covered later in .

This button launches the Upgrade Manager. The Upgrade Manager is used to install software upgrades, as well as schedule automatic upgrades as they are available. More information on the Upgrade Manager can be found in .
This is a Software Appliance. There are actually three such appliances shown in . Understanding the interface to Software Appliances as well as their installation is covered in .

sect1.para: It should be noted that the Software Appliances shown in are divided into two sections - the Default Rack and System Services. The distinction between the two is important only when using multiple Virtual Racks and Policies (an advanced topic, covered in ).

sect1.title: Software Appliances
sect1.para: One of the unique features of the ⪚ is the ability to add and remove Software Appliances to fit the needs of your deployment. Each Software Appliance has a dedicated function to enhance your network, and can be installed/configured independently of other appliances.

Although Software Appliances act independently, they share many common interface characteristics. They are all installed by clicking on the appliance from the Toolbox. This causes an appliance to be installed into the rack to the right.
The system will prevent you from installing the same type of appliance into the same rack more than.
Once installed, each appliance shows its faceplate. A sample faceplate is shown in .
The image in is annotated with numbers, corresponding to components of each Software Appliance. Explanation of these components is as follows.

listitem.para:
The on/off button for the Software Appliance. Pushing the button with the mouse toggles the on/off state.
When you first install a Software Appliance, it is turned off.
Power indicator light. This is green when the Software Appliance is on, and gray when off.

Each Software Appliance has one or more Activity Meter. Activity meters provide a quick view into the activity of a Software Appliance. They change in real time as a given Software Appliance processes network traffic.
The Activity Meters are a quick means to see if a given Software Appliance is working. Although the data may be interesting, much more detailed information can be obtained from the Edge Reports Software Appliance (see ) as well as the Event Logs for each appliance. More on Event Logs shortly.
The visual icon, identifying the Software Appliance. Each Software Appliance has a unique icon.
The Show Settings button launches screens to configure each Software Appliance.

sect1.para: Most Software Appliances have an Event Log as part of their controls. The Event Logs are seen by expanding the settings (the Show Settings button in ).

The Event Logs for each Software Appliance present a table of interesting events which were observed by the ⪚. Sometimes they simply provide a dialog of which traffic was filtered (...examined this web request from 1.2.3.4 and found no viruses...). Other times, they indicate malicious content which was stopped by the Software Appliance (...blocked email with subject 'Urgent Business Request' as it was found to be a phishing email...).
The set and meaning of columns depends on the Software Appliance, and is discussed in the documentation for each.
